subs.text: 1/6 I'm thinking a lot about RSS this year.
subs.rawText: 1/6 I'm thinking a lot about RSS this year.

subs.text: 2/6 As a reader, I have no problem with a publishing site like Substack only doing outbound RSS. All my reading tools can hook into their authors' writing. It's good.
subs.rawText: 2/6 As a reader, I have no problem with a publishing site like Substack only doing outbound RSS. All my reading tools can hook into their authors' writing. It's good.

subs.text: 3/6 But as a writer, I can't use a system that doesn't do inbound RSS. It's the inverse of the silo problem.
subs.rawText: 3/6 But as a writer, I can't use a system that doesn't do inbound RSS. It's the inverse of the silo problem.

subs.text: 4/6 Such a site insists that I do all my writing on there. That's a deal-stopper because I already have my best writing tool and I do all my serious writing in that tool. It's as if a radio station insisted that I use their guitar to play music.
subs.rawText: 4/6 Such a site insists that I do all my writing on there. That's a deal-stopper because I already have my best writing tool and I do all my serious writing in that tool. It's as if a radio station insisted that I use their guitar to play music.

subs.text: 5/6 Someday we'll look back on this practice and think how could we have missed something so obvious.
subs.rawText: 5/6 Someday we'll look back on this practice and think how could we have missed something so obvious.

subs.text: 6/6 I've asked writers who use Substack how they feel about this, with mixed results. None of the writers are thinking about it very much, apparently.

subs.text: i spent a lot of years learning how to do software demos, and then how to design software to demo well. it's important, otherwise your ideas and what you learn exist in a vacuum, and can't influence anyone.
subs.rawText: i spent a lot of years learning how to do software demos, and then how to design software to demo well. it's important, otherwise your ideas and what you learn exist in a vacuum, and can't influence anyone.

subs.text: i know what it's like to be an expert in abstractions, that's what i am -- but you have to make it real for people who aren't experts and don't think in abstractions.
subs.rawText: i know what it's like to be an expert in abstractions, that's what i am -- but you have to make it real for people who aren't experts and don't think in abstractions.

subs.text: then you test your demos with real people. see if they get anything from your demo. let them ask questions, if they don't have any the demo didn't work. if their questions have nothing to do with what you demoed it didn't work.
subs.rawText: then you test your demos with real people. see if they get anything from your demo. let them ask questions, if they don't have any the demo didn't work. if their questions have nothing to do with what you demoed it didn't work.

subs.text: how many demos have you seen where the demoer spends the first 10 minutes talking before doing any demoing? the demo begins immediately (unless you're steve jobs in his prime, when you get to tease).
subs.rawText: how many demos have you seen where the demoer spends the first 10 minutes talking before doing any demoing? the demo begins immediately (unless you're steve jobs in his prime, when you get to tease).

subs.text: and you practice relentlessly, so when it finally comes time to do the big demo you could do it in your dreams.
subs.rawText: and you practice relentlessly, so when it finally comes time to do the big demo you could do it in your dreams.
